questions.text: What is the most common functioning tumor of the pituitary?
questions.solution:
Prolactin-secreting adenoma or prolactinoma is the most common type of functioning pituitary adenoma. Pituitary adenomas are the most common type of pituitary tumor, accounting for one-third of all tumors.

Related Pearl: Classification of Pituitary Adenomas with Associated Syndromes

questions.text: What are the most common cells involved in non-functioning pituitary adenoma?
questions.solution:
Non-functioning pituitary adenomas most commonly arise from gonadotropic cells (80%). 

Pituitary adenomas are classified as functioning or non-functioning based on the secretion of hormones. Non-functioning adenomas are usually asymptomatic in the initial stages but as the tumor grows larger, mass effect produces clinical manifestations such as:

  • Headache
  • Bitemporal hemianopia 
  • Diplopia, ptosis 
  • Compression of pituitary stalk
    • Hyperprolactinemia initially - reduced dopamine release leads to loss of inhibition of lactotrophs
    • Hypopituitarism in later stages

Related Pearl: Cells of Anterior Pituitary

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a suspected prolactinoma is planned for a brain MRI. What size would the tumor have to be to call it a microadenoma?
questions.solution:
Pituitary adenomas < 10 mm are called microadenomas.

Asymptomatic pituitary tumors can be discovered incidentally on imaging. They must also be suspected in patients with features of hormone hypersecretion or mass effect. In such cases, MRI with contrast is the best investigation to detect the tumor, as shown below. 

Levels of pituitary hormones must also be measured to rule out both hypersecretion and hyposecretion.

questions.text: Which of the following would not occur in a patient with a pituitary macroadenoma?

choices.text: Low serum thyroxine and TSH levels

questions.solution:
Pituitary macroadenomas do not cause pigmentation of mucous membranes as ACTH levels are low.

In this condition, there is destruction of the pituitary gland by mass effect. This leads to panhypopituitarism or reduced levels of all hormones, including ACTH. Excessive pigmentation is only seen in cases of excess ACTH.

The following hormones are deficient in panhypopituitarism:

  • ACTH - Secondary adrenal insufficiency
  • TSH - Secondary hypothyroidism
  • GH - Growth failure and adult hyposomatotropism
  • FSH, LH - Hypogonadic hypogonadism
  • Prolactin - Lactation failure

Adiponectin, secreted by fat cells normally increases insulin sensitivity. It is usually suppressed by cortisol. In panhypopituitarism, decreased cortisol levels lead to increased insulin sensitivity.

questions.text: Which of the following can occur in a patient with prolactinoma?
questions.solution:
Superior quadrantanopia may be seen in patients with prolactinoma > 10 mm in size (macroadenoma).

In this condition, visual field defects occur due to compression of the optic chiasm. In the initial stages, the pituitary tumor tends to compress the ventral portion of the optic chiasm. This causes a bitemporal (heteronymous) superior field defect. As the tumor grows larger, the entire optic chiasm gets compressed, leading to complete bitemporal hemianopia, as shown below. 

Damage to the optic radiation in the temporal lobe would result in homonymous superior quadrantanopia or pie-in-the-sky appearance.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: What levels of prolactin are definitely suggestive of prolactinoma?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of a prolactinoma is highly likely when prolactin levels are > 200 μg/L.

The normal range of serum prolactin (PRL) is 5-20 μg/L. Prolactin levels < 100 μg/L can be due to non-functioning pituitary adenomas or non-neoplastic causes of hyperprolactinemia. MRI brain must be done in all patients with hyperprolactinemia.

Prolactinoma are tumors arising from the lactotroph cells of the pituitary gland, they can be classified as microadenoma(<1cm in diameter, usually non invasive ) or macroadenoma(>1cm, locally invasive to adjacent structures). Clinical features include amenorrhea, infertility, and galactorrhea in women, impotence, loss of libido, infertility in men and if tumor extends beyond sella, there can be visual field defects and other mass effects.

Treatment - In asymptomatic patients and those where fertility is not desired, they do not require treatment and can be monitored using regular PRL measurements and MRI. In symptomatic microadenoma cases, oral dopamine agonists (cabergoline and bromocriptine) form the main treatment for hyperprolactinemia and reduction of tumor volume. For macroadenoma, before starting dopamine agonists visual field testing is to be done, and reassess it with MRI changes every 6-12 month intervals until maximum reduction is achieved, in unresponsive cases consider surgery.

questions.text: Patients with which of the following conditions do not need to be screened for pituitary tumors?
questions.solution:
MEN2 syndrome is not associated with pituitary tumors. It is associated with medullary thyroid cancer and pheochromocytoma.

The genetic syndromes associated with pituitary tumors include:

  • MEN1
  • MEN4
  • Carney complex tumors
  • McCune-Albright Syndrome

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presented with a gradually diminishing visual field. She was found to have a pituitary mass and underwent trans-sphenoidal hypophysectomy. Now she has low levels of ACTH, TSH, FSH, and LH. Which of the following hormone supplements is not needed in the patient postoperatively?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a woman presenting with hypopituitarism following trans-sphenoidal resection. Mineralocorticoid supplementation is not needed postoperatively as it is regulated by the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system and not by ACTH. Therefore, mineralocorticoid levels would remain intact despite ACTH deficiency.

Thyroid hormone, estradiol, and glucocorticoid supplementation are needed in this patient as their secretion is regulated by anterior pituitary hormones.

Features of hypopituitarism include growth abnormalities in children with a growth hormone deficiency, insufficient levels of gonadotropins leading to menstrual irregularities, infertility in women and reduced sexual function, infertility and loss of secondary sexual characteristics in men. TSH deficiency leads to stunted growth in children and features of hypothyroidism in both children and adults. ACTH deficiency leads to secondary adrenal insufficiency.

Polyuria and polydipsia may be seen and indicate a loss of vasopressin secretion in posterior pituitary lesions.

The following hormones must be replaced post-hypophysectomy:

Trophic hormone deficit

Hormone Replacement

ACTH

Hydrocortisone, cortisone acetate, prednisone 
TSH

L-thyroxine (75–150 µg daily)
FSH/LH
Males: Testosterone
 
Females: 

For fertility: menopausal gonadotropins, hCG

Post-menopausal women: Conjugated estrogen, progesterone
GH

Somatotropin
Vasopressin

Intranasal desmopressin

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common clinical presentation in patients with craniopharyngiomas?
questions.solution:
Headache is the most common presenting symptom of craniopharyngioma.

Craniopharyngiomas are benign, suprasellar cystic masses. They have a bimodal distribution, occurring predominantly in children but also between the ages of 55 and 65 years. It can present with the following clinical symptoms:

  • Headache
  • Hypopituitarism
    • Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism
    • Central diabetes insipidus
  • Bitemporal hemianopia
  • Raised ICT - vomiting, papilledema, hydrocephalus

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is referred for evaluation of progressively worsening headaches and visual field defects. An MRI brain is done and shows the following findings. Which of the following statements is incorrect about this condition?

choices.text: Surgery is curative in most patients
Calcifications are seen in adamantinomatous type

questions.solution:
The given MRI showing a suprasellar mass with calcifications is suggestive of a craniopharyngioma. Surgery is not curative in the majority of patients as the tumor is adherent to surrounding structures.

They are benign epithelial cell-containing tumors and are of two types:

  • Adamantinomatous - calcifications and keratin nodules are seen
  • Papillary - calcifications are rare

Biopsy reveals machinery or motor-oil-like fluid within the cyst that contains cholesterol crystals. The treatment of choice is transcranial or transsphenoidal resection. It must be followed by postoperative radiation to prevent recurrence.

questions.text: Patients with which of the following conditions are not at risk for pituitary apoplexy?
questions.solution:
Pituitary apoplexy does not occur in hyperthyroidism. It is a rare endocrine emergency which can occur due to haemorrhage or infarction of the pituitary gland. It may occur as a result of the following conditions:

  • Pituitary adenoma (spontaneous)
  • Sheehan syndrome
  • Acute shock
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Hypertension
  • Sickle cell anemia

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in pituitary apoplexy?
questions.solution:
Shock is seen in pituitary apoplexy.

Loss of consciousness (Option C) can also be seen but it occurs secondary to adrenal insufficiency and shock. Hence, shock is the most appropriate answer.

Pituitary apoplexy refers to acute hemorrhagic infarction of the pituitary gland. This results in the compression of surrounding structures and hypopituitarism leading to acute adrenal insufficiency. It may be seen spontaneously in a pre-existing pituitary adenoma, post-partum (Sheehan’s syndrome), or be associated with hypertension, diabetes mellitus or sickle cell anemia or shock.

Pituitary apoplexy is an endocrine emergency that can lead to severe hypoglycemia, hypotension, shock, central nervous system (CNS) hemorrhage, and death. Acute clinical manifestations commonly encompass intense headaches with signs of meningeal irritation, bilateral visual changes, ophthalmoplegia, and even cardiovascular collapse.

The investigation of choice is MRI. 

Patients who do not exhibit overt visual impairment or altered mental status can be managed conservatively with high-dose glucocorticoids. Progressive visual loss, cranial nerve palsy, or altered mental status necessitate expeditious surgical decompression.

questions.text: Which hormone is the first to fall in Sheehan syndrome?
questions.solution:
Growth hormone (GH) is the first to fall in Sheehan syndrome. The hormones are affected in the order of GH → Prolactin → LH and FSH → ACTH → TSH

Sheehan syndrome refers to postpartum pituitary necrosis following severe postpartum hemorrhage (PPH). During pregnancy, the pituitary gland undergoes hypertrophy with increased blood supply. This makes it susceptible to ischemia and infarction when there is severe hypovolemia.

The clinical presentation depends on the amount of damage to the pituitary.

  • Mild - can go unnoticed for many years
  • Moderate - develops over months
    • Lactation failure
    • Failure to resume menses
    • Mild fatigue and anorexia
  • Severe - endocrine emergency that develops within few days
    • Hypotension and shock
    • Severe hypoglycemia
    • Lactation failure

GH deficiency is very common in Sheehan’s syndrome because somatotrophs are located in the lower and lateral regions of the pituitary gland, and are most likely to be damaged by ischemic necrosis of the pituitary.

questions.text: You are a first-year resident in the postpartum ward. During rounds, you see a 28-year-old woman who has been unable to breastfeed since delivery. Her baby was born by normal vaginal delivery that was complicated by severe postpartum hemorrhage. Her blood pressure is 90/50 mm Hg and her pulse is 96/min. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution: This clinical scenario is suggestive of Sheehan syndrome. Corticosteroids must be supplemented first, as life-threatening manifestations may occur due to the sudden onset of adrenal insufficiency. This is followed by the replacement of other deficient pituitary hormones including thyroid hormone and estrogen administered with or without progesterone.
